bioghist.p: Presbyterians for Democracy and Religious Freedom is a caucus for reform in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). Their goal is to encourage open debate within the denomination about political affairs. They believe that the church, as stated in the barmen declaration, must never, "appropriate the characteristics, the task, and the dignity of the state," nor "Place the word and work of the Lord in the service of any arbitrarily chosen desires, purposes, and plans." PDRF's objectives are educational -- to make available to members of the PC(USA) "additional and alternative views" and its guiding principle is that "democracy, while falling far short of our vision of the kingdom of God, permits the greatest possibility of and freedom for carrying out the Christian calling to proclaim as well as to live out the gospel."

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of reports of the Presbyterians for Democracy and Religious Freedom. "Central America Focus," by K. L. Billingsley is a 1988 response to a report of the 199th General Assembly entitled "Central America Update." There is also a series of essays entitled "Peacemaking? Or Resistance?: Presbyterian Perspectives" edited by Ted M. Dorman. The essays are a response to the Advisory Council on Church and Society's booklet entitled "Presbyterians and Peacemaking: Are We Now Called to Resistance?"
